author: larryi
msg: Since exceptions are now being propagated, changes were need to
properly handle exceptions thrown during initialization.
Probably need to review how much is going in the log due to exception
propagation.  It might be a bit much.

author: larryi
msg: Since exceptions are now being propagated, changes were need to
properly handle exceptions thrown during initialization.
Additional changes include:
The servlet instance is now release if an exception is thrown during
initialization.  I think the spec requires this.
Handling has been added for UnavailableExceptions thrown during the
request procession.  Previously they were ignored.  The servlet should
become unavailable for the appropriate amount of time (this needs some
testing).  However, permanently UnavailableExceptions don't yet destroy
the servlet as called for in the spec.  I think the synchronization of servlet
destruction needs some review before doing this to insure we don't deadlock.
For simplification, stillUnavailable() was replaced with servletAvailable(), which
throws an appropriate exception rather than return a boolean.  Also,
handleUnavailable was removed since the handling has been moved to
ContextManager's handleError() method. and handleNotFound was removed
since it wasn't used anywhere.

author: larryi
msg: Moved UnavailableException handling from ServletWrapper to
ContextManger's handleError method.
This allows UnavailableExceptions to be handled by a call to handleErro()
from Handler's service() method, along with other exceptions.  This is cleaner
than trying to keep handling for UnavailableExceptions local to
ServletWrapper when exceptions are being propagated.

author: larryi
msg: Adding a property to indicate if error handling has been performed.
Since Handler and ServletWrapper will be propagating exceptions, we
need a way to determine if the exception has been handled at a higher
level.

author: larryi
msg: Since ServletWrapper's service() method can now throw exceptions, we
need to catch these exceptions in include() so the request can be restored.
Then rethrow the exception.
